Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology for FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Postdoctoral Fellowships in Biology combine research and training components to prepare young scientists for careers in emerging areas where biology intersects with other scientific disciplines, in this case with mathematics and physical sciences. The Fellows are expected to be leaders of the nation's scientific workforce in the future. This fellowship to Sarah R. Supp supports a research and training plan at the intersection of biology, statistics, and computer science and examines how body size responds to environmental change. The host institutions for this fellowship are the University of Maine and the University of Vermont, and the sponsoring scientists are Brian McGill and Nicholas Gotelli.

It is difficult to describe, predict, and preserve biodiversity in the face of rapid environmental change, yet these are critical goals for conservation efforts. A macroecological approach to understanding diversity uses patterns, e.g., body size, that exhibit regular behavior across taxonomic groups, ecosystems, and continents. This research develops a dynamic framework for macroecology through 1) data aggregation and access, 2) mechanistic complex system modeling, and 3) cross-scale analysis. Body size patterns integrate taxonomic, functional, and trait diversity, and changes to these patterns are being shown to be vital to understanding changes in ecosystem function. Size patterns are expected to be sensitive to perturbation since mechanisms that influence body size include species interactions and energetic constraints, which can be rapidly impacted in human-altered landscapes. These interactions are being studied by developing and using an interactive model for predicting pattern response to global change scenarios. Training goals include developing expertise in data informatics and advanced statistical and computational modeling techniques. Broader impacts include development of undergraduate courses, participation by under-represented groups, computer science outreach programs, online science communication, and open-access sharing of all research products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sarah Supp has completed her research for her Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in the Intersections of Biological and Mathematical, and Physical Sciences, “Globally assessing body size response to environmental change”. She completed this work under the mentorship of sponsoring scientists Dr. Brian McGill at the University of Maine and Dr. Nicholas Gotelli at the University of Vermont. During her funding period, she spent time at the University of Maine and the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and collaborated broadly with a network of biodiversity scientists in North America and Europe. Through these collaborations, the research contributed to aggregating dispersed records of recent (past 100 years) biodiversity change (that include species- and individual-based measures), descriptions of the scale-dependence and biogeographic patterning of biodiversity change, and hypotheses for body size response to environmental change scenarios.

 

Understanding patterns of recent biodiversity change is difficult, as biodiversity is a multi-faceted concept that can be measured in many different ways (species richness, species identity, abundance, and individual body size), and each different measure exhibits different responses to (human or natural) drivers of change. Yet, describing and predicting different facets of biodiversity response, is a critical need for effective conservation planning and intervention. Across broad scales, a macroecological approach to biodiversity can help to identify patterns that exhibit regular behavior in taxonomic groups, ecosystems, and continents, and thus, more clearly identify systems that deviate from the expectation. The goals of this study were to (1) develop data and research schema to improve our understanding of global biodiversity change, (2) Collaborate and communicate across the boundaries of macroecology, conservation biology, and statistics, and (3) develop research-informed teaching practices that increase the participation and inclusion of underrepresented groups in STEM fields.

 

The completed project contributed to building new collaborative research networks and teaching computational skills to graduate women in science and engineering. Particularly, there was a focus in statistical, analytical, and educational training that aimed to advance the postdoctoral fellow’s career and research agenda in ecology and data science. As a result of this fellowship, Sarah Supp has now begun a tenure-track faculty position in a new Data Analytics program at Denison University. She is using her fellowship training to teach and encourage a diverse set of undergraduate students broad computational, statistical and communication skill sets for data science, across student focal areas including biology, economics, and psychology. Within 1 year of project completion, the scientific results will have been shared at several invited university seminars (3), domestic conferences (2), and through the publication of peer-reviewed manuscripts (4 pending). The biodiversity and body size change research program begun in this project will continue to inform the field through the mentoring and training of undergraduate student researchers, and continued broad collaborative networks.
